text: These are the words that Moses spoke to all the people of Israel while they were in the wilderness east of the Jordan River. They were camped in the Jordan Valley near Suph, between Paran on one side and Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth, and Di-zahab on the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Normally it takes only eleven days to travel from Mount Sinai to Kadesh-barnea, going by way of Mount Seir.
speaker: Narrator

text: But forty years after the Israelites left Egypt, on the first day of the eleventh month, Moses addressed the people of Israel, telling them everything the Lord had commanded him to say.
speaker: Narrator

text: This took place after he had defeated King Sihon of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon, and at Edrei had defeated King Og of Bashan, who ruled in Ashtaroth.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the Israelites were in the land of Moab east of the Jordan River, Moses carefully explained the Lord’s instructions as follows.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When we were at Mount Sinai, the Lord our God said to us, ‘You have stayed at this mountain long enough.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is time to break camp and move on. Go to the hill country of the Amorites and to all the neighboring regions—the Jordan Valley, the hill country, the western foothills, the Negev, and the coastal plain. Go to the land of the Canaanites and to Lebanon, and all the way to the great Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, I am giving all this land to you! Go in and occupy it, for it is the land the Lord swore to give to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and to all their descendants.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses continued, “At that time I told you, ‘You are too great a burden for me to carry all by myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God has increased your population, making you as numerous as the stars!
speaker: Narrator

text: And may the Lord, the God of your ancestors, multiply you a thousand times more and bless you as he promised!
speaker: Narrator

text: But you are such a heavy load to carry! How can I deal with all your problems and bickering?
speaker: Narrator

text: Choose some well-respected men from each tribe who are known for their wisdom and understanding, and I will appoint them as your leaders.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then you responded, ‘Your plan is a good one.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I took the wise and respected men you had selected from your tribes and appointed them to serve as judges and officials over you. Some were responsible for a thousand people, some for a hundred, some for fifty, and some for ten.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I instructed the judges, ‘You must hear the cases of your fellow Israelites and the foreigners living among you. Be perfectly fair in your decisions
speaker: Narrator

text: and impartial in your judgments. Hear the cases of those who are poor as well as those who are rich. Don’t be afraid of anyone’s anger, for the decision you make is God’s decision. Bring me any cases that are too difficult for you, and I will handle them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I gave you instructions about everything you were to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then, just as the Lord our God commanded us, we left Mount Sinai and traveled through the great and terrifying wilderness, as you yourselves remember, and headed toward the hill country of the Amorites. When we arrived at Kadesh-barnea,
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to you, ‘You have now reached the hill country of the Amorites that the Lord our God is giving us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look! He has placed the land in front of you. Go and occupy it as the Lord, the God of your ancestors, has promised you. Don’t be afraid! Don’t be discouraged!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you all came to me and said, ‘First, let’s send out scouts to explore the land for us. They will advise us on the best route to take and which towns we should enter.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This seemed like a good idea to me, so I chose twelve scouts, one from each of your tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: They headed for the hill country and came to the valley of Eshcol and explored it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They picked some of its fruit and brought it back to us. And they reported, ‘The land the Lord our God has given us is indeed a good land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you rebelled against the command of the Lord your God and refused to go in.
speaker: Narrator

text: You complained in your tents and said, ‘The Lord must hate us. That’s why he has brought us here from Egypt—to hand us over to the Amorites to be slaughtered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where can we go? Our brothers have demoralized us with their report. They tell us, “The people of the land are taller and more powerful than we are, and their towns are large, with walls rising high into the sky! We even saw giants there—the descendants of Anak!”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I said to you, ‘Don’t be shocked or afraid of them!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God is going ahead of you. He will fight for you, just as you saw him do in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you saw how the Lord your God cared for you all along the way as you traveled through the wilderness, just as a father cares for his child. Now he has brought you to this place.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But even after all he did, you refused to trust the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: who goes before you looking for the best places to camp, guiding you with a pillar of fire by night and a pillar of cloud by day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord heard your complaining, he became very angry. So he solemnly swore,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Not one of you from this wicked generation will live to see the good land I swore to give your ancestors,
speaker: Narrator

text: except Caleb son of Jephunneh. He will see this land because he has followed the Lord completely. I will give to him and his descendants some of the very land he explored during his scouting mission.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And the Lord was also angry with me because of you. He said to me, ‘Moses, not even you will enter the Promised Land!
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, your assistant, Joshua son of Nun, will lead the people into the land. Encourage him, for he will lead Israel as they take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give the land to your little ones—your innocent children. You were afraid they would be captured, but they will be the ones who occupy it.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, turn around now and go on back through the wilderness toward the Red Sea.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then you confessed, ‘We have sinned against the Lord! We will go into the land and fight for it, as the Lord our God has commanded us.’ So your men strapped on their weapons, thinking it would be easy to attack the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the Lord told me to tell you, ‘Do not attack, for I am not with you. If you go ahead on your own, you will be crushed by your enemies.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what I told you, but you would not listen. Instead, you again rebelled against the Lord’s command and arrogantly went into the hill country to fight.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Amorites who lived there came out against you like a swarm of bees. They chased and battered you all the way from Seir to Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you returned and wept before the Lord, but he refused to listen.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you stayed there at Kadesh for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then we turned around and headed back across the wilderness toward the Red Sea, just as the Lord had instructed me, and we wandered around in the region of Mount Seir for a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then at last the Lord said to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You have been wandering around in this hill country long enough; turn to the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give these orders to the people: “You will pass through the country belonging to your relatives the Edomites, the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir. The Edomites will feel threatened, so be careful.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bother them, for I have given them all the hill country around Mount Seir as their property, and I will not give you even one square foot of their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you need food to eat or water to drink, pay them for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God has blessed you in everything you have done. He has watched your every step through this great wilderness. During these forty years, the Lord your God has been with you, and you have lacked nothing.”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“So we bypassed the territory of our relatives, the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir. We avoided the road through the Arabah Valley that comes up from Elath and Ezion-geber.
“Then as we turned north along the desert route through Moab,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord warned us, ‘Do not bother the Moabites, the descendants of Lot, or start a war with them. I have given them Ar as their property, and I will not give you any of their land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: (A race of giants called the Emites had once lived in the area of Ar. They were as strong and numerous and tall as the Anakites, another race of giants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Both the Emites and the Anakites are also known as the Rephaites, though the Moabites call them Emites.
speaker: Narrator

text: In earlier times the Horites had lived in Seir, but they were driven out and displaced by the descendants of Esau, just as Israel drove out the people of Canaan when the Lord gave Israel their land.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses continued, “Then the Lord said to us, ‘Get moving. Cross the Zered Brook.’ So we crossed the brook.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thirty-eight years passed from the time we first left Kadesh-barnea until we finally crossed the Zered Brook! By then, all the men old enough to fight in battle had died in the wilderness, as the Lord had vowed would happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord struck them down until they had all been eliminated from the community.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When all the men of fighting age had died,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord said to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Today you will cross the border of Moab at Ar
speaker: Narrator

text: and enter the land of the Ammonites, the descendants of Lot. But do not bother them or start a war with them. I have given the land of Ammon to them as their property, and I will not give you any of their land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: (That area was once considered the land of the Rephaites, who had lived there, though the Ammonites call them Zamzummites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were also as strong and numerous and tall as the Anakites. But the Lord destroyed them so the Ammonites could occupy their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had done the same for the descendants of Esau who lived in Seir, for he destroyed the Horites so they could settle there in their place. The descendants of Esau live there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: A similar thing happened when the Caphtorites from Crete invaded and destroyed the Avvites, who had lived in villages in the area of Gaza.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses continued, “Then the Lord said, ‘Now get moving! Cross the Arnon Gorge. Look, I will hand over to you Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, and I will give you his land. Attack him and begin to occupy the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beginning today I will make people throughout the earth terrified because of you. When they hear reports about you, they will tremble with dread and fear.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses continued, “From the wilderness of Kedemoth I sent ambassadors to King Sihon of Heshbon with this proposal of peace:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Let us travel through your land. We will stay on the main road and won’t turn off into the fields on either side.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sell us food to eat and water to drink, and we will pay for it. All we want is permission to pass through your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Esau who live in Seir allowed us to go through their country, and so did the Moabites, who live in Ar. Let us pass through until we cross the Jordan into the land the Lord our God is giving us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But King Sihon of Heshbon refused to allow us to pass through, because the Lord your God made Sihon stubborn and defiant so he could help you defeat him, as he has now done.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord said to me, ‘Look, I have begun to hand King Sihon and his land over to you. Begin now to conquer and occupy his land.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then King Sihon declared war on us and mobilized his forces at Jahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord our God handed him over to us, and we crushed him, his sons, and all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: We conquered all his towns and completely destroyed everyone—men, women, and children. Not a single person was spared.
speaker: Narrator

text: We took all the livestock as plunder for ourselves, along with anything of value from the towns we ransacked.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord our God also helped us conquer Aroer on the edge of the Arnon Gorge, and the town in the gorge, and the whole area as far as Gilead. No town had walls too strong for us.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, we avoided the land of the Ammonites all along the Jabbok River and the towns in the hill country—all the places the Lord our God had commanded us to leave alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next we turned and headed for the land of Bashan, where King Og and his entire army attacked us at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord told me, ‘Do not be afraid of him, for I have given you victory over Og and his entire army, and I will give you all his land. Treat him just as you treated King Sihon of the Amorites, who ruled in Heshbon.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So the Lord our God handed King Og and all his people over to us, and we killed them all. Not a single person survived.
speaker: Narrator

text: We conquered all sixty of his towns—the entire Argob region in his kingdom of Bashan. Not a single town escaped our conquest.
speaker: Narrator

text: These towns were all fortified with high walls and barred gates. We also took many unwalled villages at the same time.
speaker: Narrator

text: We completely destroyed the kingdom of Bashan, just as we had destroyed King Sihon of Heshbon. We destroyed all the people in every town we conquered—men, women, and children alike.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we kept all the livestock for ourselves and took plunder from all the towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So we took the land of the two Amorite kings east of the Jordan River—all the way from the Arnon Gorge to Mount Hermon.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Mount Hermon is called Sirion by the Sidonians, and the Amorites call it Senir.)
speaker: Narrator

text: We had now conquered all the cities on the plateau and all Gilead and Bashan, as far as the towns of Salecah and Edrei, which were part of Og’s kingdom in Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (King Og of Bashan was the last survivor of the giant Rephaites. His bed was made of iron and was more than thirteen feet long and six feet wide. It can still be seen in the Ammonite city of Rabbah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: “When we took possession of this land, I gave to the tribes of Reuben and Gad the territory beyond Aroer along the Arnon Gorge, plus half of the hill country of Gilead with its towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I gave the rest of Gilead and all of Bashan—Og’s former kingdom—to the half-tribe of Manasseh. (This entire Argob region of Bashan used to be known as the land of the Rephaites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jair, a leader from the tribe of Manasseh, conquered the whole Argob region in Bashan, all the way to the border of the Geshurites and Maacathites. Jair renamed this region after himself, calling it the Towns of Jair, as it is still known today.)
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave Gilead to the clan of Makir.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I also gave part of Gilead to the tribes of Reuben and Gad. The area I gave them extended from the middle of the Arnon Gorge in the south to the Jabbok River on the Ammonite frontier.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also received the Jordan Valley, all the way from the Sea of Galilee down to the Dead Sea, with the Jordan River serving as the western boundary. To the east were the slopes of Pisgah.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I gave this command to the tribes that would live east of the Jordan: ‘Although the Lord your God has given you this land as your property, all your fighting men must cross the Jordan ahead of your Israelite relatives, armed and ready to assist them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your wives, children, and numerous livestock, however, may stay behind in the towns I have given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord has given security to the rest of the Israelites, as he has to you, and when they occupy the land the Lord your God is giving them across the Jordan River, then you may all return here to the land I have given you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I gave Joshua this charge: ‘You have seen for yourself everything the Lord your God has done to these two kings. He will do the same to all the kingdoms on the west side of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be afraid of the nations there, for the Lord your God will fight for you.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time I pleaded with the Lord and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘O Sovereign Lord, you have only begun to show your greatness and the strength of your hand to me, your servant. Is there any god in heaven or on earth who can perform such great and mighty deeds as you do?
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let me cross the Jordan to see the wonderful land on the other side, the beautiful hill country and the Lebanon mountains.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the Lord was angry with me because of you, and he would not listen to me. ‘That’s enough!’ he declared. ‘Speak of it no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: But go up to Pisgah Peak, and look over the land in every direction. Take a good look, but you may not cross the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, commission Joshua and encourage and strengthen him, for he will lead the people across the Jordan. He will give them all the land you now see before you as their possession.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So we stayed in the valley near Beth-peor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, Israel, listen carefully to these decrees and regulations that I am about to teach you. Obey them so that you may live, so you may enter and occupy the land that the Lord, the God of your ancestors, is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not add to or subtract from these commands I am giving you. Just obey the commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You saw for yourself what the Lord did to you at Baal-peor. There the Lord your God destroyed everyone who had worshiped Baal, the god of Peor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But all of you who were faithful to the Lord your God are still alive today—every one of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, I now teach you these decrees and regulations just as the Lord my God commanded me, so that you may obey them in the land you are about to enter and occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey them completely, and you will display your wisdom and intelligence among the surrounding nations. When they hear all these decrees, they will exclaim, ‘How wise and prudent are the people of this great nation!’
speaker: Narrator

text: For what great nation has a god as near to them as the Lord our God is near to us whenever we call on him?
speaker: Narrator

text: And what great nation has decrees and regulations as righteous and fair as this body of instructions that I am giving you today?
speaker: Narrator

text: “But watch out! Be careful never to forget what you yourself have seen. Do not let these memories escape from your mind as long as you live! And be sure to pass them on to your children and grandchildren.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never forget the day when you stood before the Lord your God at Mount Sinai, where he told me, ‘Summon the people before me, and I will personally instruct them. Then they will learn to fear me as long as they live, and they will teach their children to fear me also.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “You came near and stood at the foot of the mountain, while flames from the mountain shot into the sky. The mountain was shrouded in black clouds and deep darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord spoke to you from the heart of the fire. You heard the sound of his words but didn’t see his form; there was only a voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: He proclaimed his covenant—the Ten Commandments—which he commanded you to keep, and which he wrote on two stone tablets.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was at that time that the Lord commanded me to teach you his decrees and regulations so you would obey them in the land you are about to enter and occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But be very careful! You did not see the Lord’s form on the day he spoke to you from the heart of the fire at Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: So do not corrupt yourselves by making an idol in any form—whether of a man or a woman,
speaker: Narrator

text: an animal on the ground, a bird in the sky,
speaker: Narrator

text: a small animal that scurries along the ground, or a fish in the deepest sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when you look up into the sky and see the sun, moon, and stars—all the forces of heaven—don’t be seduced into worshiping them. The Lord your God gave them to all the peoples of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that the Lord rescued you from the iron-smelting furnace of Egypt in order to make you his very own people and his special possession, which is what you are today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the Lord was angry with me because of you. He vowed that I would not cross the Jordan River into the good land the Lord your God is giving you as your special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will cross the Jordan to occupy the land, but I will not. Instead, I will die here on the east side of the river.
speaker: Narrator

text: So be careful not to break the covenant the Lord your God has made with you. Do not make idols of any shape or form, for the Lord your God has forbidden this.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God is a devouring fire; he is a jealous God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the future, when you have children and grandchildren and have lived in the land a long time, do not corrupt yourselves by making idols of any kind. This is evil in the sight of the Lord your God and will arouse his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Today I call on heaven and earth as witnesses against you. If you break my covenant, you will quickly disappear from the land you are crossing the Jordan to occupy. You will live there only a short time; then you will be utterly destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will scatter you among the nations, where only a few of you will survive.
speaker: Narrator

text: There, in a foreign land, you will worship idols made from wood and stone—gods that neither see nor hear nor eat nor smell.
speaker: Narrator

text: But from there you will search again for the Lord your God. And if you search for him with all your heart and soul, you will find him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the distant future, when you are suffering all these things, you will finally return to the Lord your God and listen to what he tells you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is a merciful God; he will not abandon you or destroy you or forget the solemn covenant he made with your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now search all of history, from the time God created people on the earth until now, and search from one end of the heavens to the other. Has anything as great as this ever been seen or heard before?
speaker: Narrator

text: Has any nation ever heard the voice of God speaking from fire—as you did—and survived?
speaker: Narrator

text: Has any other god dared to take a nation for himself out of another nation by means of trials, miraculous signs, wonders, war, a strong hand, a powerful arm, and terrifying acts? Yet that is what the Lord your God did for you in Egypt, right before your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “He showed you these things so you would know that the Lord is God and there is no other.
speaker: Narrator

text: He let you hear his voice from heaven so he could instruct you. He let you see his great fire here on earth so he could speak to you from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he loved your ancestors, he chose to bless their descendants, and he personally brought you out of Egypt with a great display of power.
speaker: Narrator

text: He drove out nations far greater than you, so he could bring you in and give you their land as your special possession, as it is today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So remember this and keep it firmly in mind: The Lord is God both in heaven and on earth, and there is no other.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you obey all the decrees and commands I am giving you today, all will be well with you and your children. I am giving you these instructions so you will enjoy a long life in the land the Lord your God is giving you for all time.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses set apart three cities of refuge east of the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who killed another person unintentionally, without previous hostility, could flee there to live in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the cities: Bezer on the wilderness plateau for the tribe of Reuben; Ramoth in Gilead for the tribe of Gad; Golan in Bashan for the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the body of instruction that Moses presented to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the laws, decrees, and regulations that Moses gave to the people of Israel when they left Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: and as they camped in the valley near Beth-peor east of the Jordan River. (This land was formerly occupied by the Amorites under King Sihon, who ruled from Heshbon. But Moses and the Israelites destroyed him and his people when they came up from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel took possession of his land and that of King Og of Bashan—the two Amorite kings east of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel conquered the entire area from Aroer at the edge of the Arnon Gorge all the way to Mount Sirion, also called Mount Hermon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they conquered the eastern bank of the Jordan River as far south as the Dead Sea, below the slopes of Pisgah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses called all the people of Israel together and said, “Listen carefully, Israel. Hear the decrees and regulations I am giving you today, so you may learn them and obey them!
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord our God made a covenant with us at Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did not make this covenant with our ancestors, but with all of us who are alive today.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the mountain the Lord spoke to you face to face from the heart of the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: I stood as an intermediary between you and the Lord, for you were afraid of the fire and did not want to approach the mountain. He spoke to me, and I passed his words on to you. This is what he said:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am the Lord your God, who rescued you from the land of Egypt, the place of your slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not have any other god but me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not make for yourself an idol of any kind, or an image of anything in the heavens or on the earth or in the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not bow down to them or worship them, for I, the Lord your God, am a jealous God who will not tolerate your affection for any other gods. I lay the sins of the parents upon their children; the entire family is affected—even children in the third and fourth generations of those who reject me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I lavish unfailing love for a thousand generations on those who love me and obey my commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not misuse the name of the Lord your God. The Lord will not let you go unpunished if you misuse his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Observe the Sabbath day by keeping it holy, as the Lord your God has commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have six days each week for your ordinary work,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the seventh day is a Sabbath day of rest dedicated to the Lord your God. On that day no one in your household may do any work. This includes you, your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, your oxen and donkeys and other livestock, and any foreigners living among you. All your male and female servants must rest as you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were once slaves in Egypt, but the Lord your God brought you out with his strong hand and powerful arm. That is why the Lord your God has commanded you to rest on the Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Honor your father and mother, as the Lord your God commanded you. Then you will live a long, full life in the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not murder.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not testify falsely against your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not covet your neighbor’s wife. You must not covet your neighbor’s house or land, male or female servant, ox or donkey, or anything else that belongs to your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord spoke these words to all of you assembled there at the foot of the mountain. He spoke with a loud voice from the heart of the fire, surrounded by clouds and deep darkness. This was all he said at that time, and he wrote his words on two stone tablets and gave them to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But when you heard the voice from the heart of the darkness, while the mountain was blazing with fire, all your tribal leaders and elders came to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, ‘Look, the Lord our God has shown us his glory and greatness, and we have heard his voice from the heart of the fire. Today we have seen that God can speak to us humans, and yet we live!
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, why should we risk death again? If the Lord our God speaks to us again, we will certainly die and be consumed by this awesome fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Can any living thing hear the voice of the living God from the heart of the fire as we did and yet survive?
speaker: Narrator

text: Go yourself and listen to what the Lord our God says. Then come and tell us everything he tells you, and we will listen and obey.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord heard the request you made to me. And he said, ‘I have heard what the people said to you, and they are right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Oh, that they would always have hearts like this, that they might fear me and obey all my commands! If they did, they and their descendants would prosper forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and tell them, “Return to your tents.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But you stand here with me so I can give you all my commands, decrees, and regulations. You must teach them to the people so they can obey them in the land I am giving them as their possession.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses told the people, “You must be careful to obey all the commands of the Lord your God, following his instructions in every detail.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stay on the path that the Lord your God has commanded you to follow. Then you will live long and prosperous lives in the land you are about to enter and occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the commands, decrees, and regulations that the Lord your God commanded me to teach you. You must obey them in the land you are about to enter and occupy,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you and your children and grandchildren must fear the Lord your God as long as you live. If you obey all his decrees and commands, you will enjoy a long life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen closely, Israel, and be careful to obey. Then all will go well with you, and you will have many children in the land flowing with milk and honey, just as the Lord, the God of your ancestors, promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen, O Israel! The Lord is our God, the Lord alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must love the Lord your God with all your heart, all your soul, and all your strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must commit yourselves wholeheartedly to these commands that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Repeat them again and again to your children. Talk about them when you are at home and when you are on the road, when you are going to bed and when you are getting up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tie them to your hands and wear them on your forehead as reminders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write them on the doorposts of your house and on your gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will soon bring you into the land he swore to give you when he made a vow to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. It is a land with large, prosperous cities that you did not build.
speaker: Narrator

text: The houses will be richly stocked with goods you did not produce. You will draw water from cisterns you did not dig, and you will eat from vineyards and olive trees you did not plant. When you have eaten your fill in this land,
speaker: Narrator

text: be careful not to forget the Lord, who rescued you from slavery in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must fear the Lord your God and serve him. When you take an oath, you must use only his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not worship any of the gods of neighboring nations,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the Lord your God, who lives among you, is a jealous God. His anger will flare up against you, and he will wipe you from the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not test the Lord your God as you did when you complained at Massah.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must diligently obey the commands of the Lord your God—all the laws and decrees he has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do what is right and good in the Lord’s sight, so all will go well with you. Then you will enter and occupy the good land that the Lord swore to give your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will drive out all the enemies living in the land, just as the Lord said you would.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the future your children will ask you, ‘What is the meaning of these laws, decrees, and regulations that the Lord our God has commanded us to obey?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then you must tell them, ‘We were Pharaoh’s slaves in Egypt, but the Lord brought us out of Egypt with his strong hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did miraculous signs and wonders before our eyes, dealing terrifying blows against Egypt and Pharaoh and all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought us out of Egypt so he could give us this land he had sworn to give our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord our God commanded us to obey all these decrees and to fear him so he can continue to bless us and preserve our lives, as he has done to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we will be counted as righteous when we obey all the commands the Lord our God has given us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God brings you into the land you are about to enter and occupy, he will clear away many nations ahead of you: the Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites. These seven nations are greater and more numerous than you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God hands these nations over to you and you conquer them, you must completely destroy them. Make no treaties with them and show them no mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not intermarry with them. Do not let your daughters and sons marry their sons and daughters,
speaker: Narrator

text: for they will lead your children away from me to worship other gods. Then the anger of the Lord will burn against you, and he will quickly destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what you must do. You must break down their pagan altars and shatter their sacred pillars. Cut down their Asherah poles and burn their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are a holy people, who belong to the Lord your God. Of all the people on earth, the Lord your God has chosen you to be his own special treasure.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord did not set his heart on you and choose you because you were more numerous than other nations, for you were the smallest of all nations!
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, it was simply that the Lord loves you, and he was keeping the oath he had sworn to your ancestors. That is why the Lord rescued you with such a strong hand from your slavery and from the oppressive hand of Pharaoh, king of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Understand, therefore, that the Lord your God is indeed God. He is the faithful God who keeps his covenant for a thousand generations and lavishes his unfailing love on those who love him and obey his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he does not hesitate to punish and destroy those who reject him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, you must obey all these commands, decrees, and regulations I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you listen to these regulations and faithfully obey them, the Lord your God will keep his covenant of unfailing love with you, as he promised with an oath to your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will love you and bless you, and he will give you many children. He will give fertility to your land and your animals. When you arrive in the land he swore to give your ancestors, you will have large harvests of grain, new wine, and olive oil, and great herds of cattle, sheep, and goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed above all the nations of the earth. None of your men or women will be childless, and all your livestock will bear young.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord will protect you from all sickness. He will not let you suffer from the terrible diseases you knew in Egypt, but he will inflict them on all your enemies!
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must destroy all the nations the Lord your God hands over to you. Show them no mercy, and do not worship their gods, or they will trap you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps you will think to yourselves, ‘How can we ever conquer these nations that are so much more powerful than we are?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t be afraid of them! Just remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and to all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember the great terrors the Lord your God sent against them. You saw it all with your own eyes! And remember the miraculous signs and wonders, and the strong hand and powerful arm with which he brought you out of Egypt. The Lord your God will use this same power against all the people you fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: And then the Lord your God will send terror to drive out the few survivors still hiding from you!
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, do not be afraid of those nations, for the Lord your God is among you, and he is a great and awesome God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will drive those nations out ahead of you little by little. You will not clear them away all at once, otherwise the wild animals would multiply too quickly for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord your God will hand them over to you. He will throw them into complete confusion until they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will put their kings in your power, and you will erase their names from the face of the earth. No one will be able to stand against you, and you will destroy them all.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must burn their idols in fire, and you must not covet the silver or gold that covers them. You must not take it or it will become a trap to you, for it is detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not bring any detestable objects into your home, for then you will be destroyed, just like them. You must utterly detest such things, for they are set apart for destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be careful to obey all the commands I am giving you today. Then you will live and multiply, and you will enter and occupy the land the Lord swore to give your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember how the Lord your God led you through the wilderness for these forty years, humbling you and testing you to prove your character, and to find out whether or not you would obey his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, he humbled you by letting you go hungry and then feeding you with manna, a food previously unknown to you and your ancestors. He did it to teach you that people do not live by bread alone; rather, we live by every word that comes from the mouth of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all these forty years your clothes didn’t wear out, and your feet didn’t blister or swell.
speaker: Narrator

text: Think about it: Just as a parent disciplines a child, the Lord your God disciplines you for your own good.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So obey the commands of the Lord your God by walking in his ways and fearing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is bringing you into a good land of flowing streams and pools of water, with fountains and springs that gush out in the valleys and hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a land of wheat and barley; of grapevines, fig trees, and pomegranates; of olive oil and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a land where food is plentiful and nothing is lacking. It is a land where iron is as common as stone, and copper is abundant in the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have eaten your fill, be sure to praise the Lord your God for the good land he has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But that is the time to be careful! Beware that in your plenty you do not forget the Lord your God and disobey his commands, regulations, and decrees that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when you have become full and prosperous and have built fine homes to live in,
speaker: Narrator

text: and when your flocks and herds have become very large and your silver and gold have multiplied along with everything else, be careful!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not become proud at that time and forget the Lord your God, who rescued you from slavery in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not forget that he led you through the great and terrifying wilderness with its poisonous snakes and scorpions, where it was so hot and dry. He gave you water from the rock!
speaker: Narrator

text: He fed you with manna in the wilderness, a food unknown to your ancestors. He did this to humble you and test you for your own good.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did all this so you would never say to yourself, ‘I have achieved this wealth with my own strength and energy.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember the Lord your God. He is the one who gives you power to be successful, in order to fulfill the covenant he confirmed to your ancestors with an oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But I assure you of this: If you ever forget the Lord your God and follow other gods, worshiping and bowing down to them, you will certainly be destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as the Lord has destroyed other nations in your path, you also will be destroyed if you refuse to obey the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Listen, O Israel! Today you are about to cross the Jordan River to take over the land belonging to nations much greater and more powerful than you. They live in cities with walls that reach to the sky!
speaker: Narrator

text: The people are strong and tall—descendants of the famous Anakite giants. You’ve heard the saying, ‘Who can stand up to the Anakites?’
speaker: Narrator

text: But recognize today that the Lord your God is the one who will cross over ahead of you like a devouring fire to destroy them. He will subdue them so that you will quickly conquer them and drive them out, just as the Lord has promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: “After the Lord your God has done this for you, don’t say in your hearts, ‘The Lord has given us this land because we are such good people!’ No, it is because of the wickedness of the other nations that he is pushing them out of your way.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not because you are so good or have such integrity that you are about to occupy their land. The Lord your God will drive these nations out ahead of you only because of their wickedness, and to fulfill the oath he swore to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must recognize that the Lord your God is not giving you this good land because you are good, for you are not—you are a stubborn people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember and never forget how angry you made the Lord your God out in the wilderness. From the day you left Egypt until now, you have been constantly rebelling against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even at Mount Sinai you made the Lord so angry he was ready to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This happened when I was on the mountain receiving the tablets of stone inscribed with the words of the covenant that the Lord had made with you. I was there for forty days and forty nights, and all that time I ate no food and drank no water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gave me the two tablets on which God had written with his own finger all the words he had spoken to you from the heart of the fire when you were assembled at the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At the end of the forty days and nights, the Lord handed me the two stone tablets inscribed with the words of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, ‘Get up! Go down immediately, for the people you brought out of Egypt have corrupted themselves. How quickly they have turned away from the way I commanded them to live! They have melted gold and made an idol for themselves!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord also said to me, ‘I have seen how stubborn and rebellious these people are.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leave me alone so I may destroy them and erase their name from under heaven. Then I will make a mighty nation of your descendants, a nation larger and more powerful than they are.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So while the mountain was blazing with fire I turned and came down, holding in my hands the two stone tablets inscribed with the terms of the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: There below me I could see that you had sinned against the Lord your God. You had melted gold and made a calf idol for yourselves. How quickly you had turned away from the path the Lord had commanded you to follow!
speaker: Narrator

text: So I took the stone tablets and threw them to the ground, smashing them before your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then, as before, I threw myself down before the Lord for forty days and nights. I ate no bread and drank no water because of the great sin you had committed by doing what the Lord hated, provoking him to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: I feared that the furious anger of the Lord, which turned him against you, would drive him to destroy you. But again he listened to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was so angry with Aaron that he wanted to destroy him, too. But I prayed for Aaron, and the Lord spared him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I took your sin—the calf you had made—and I melted it down in the fire and ground it into fine dust. Then I threw the dust into the stream that flows down the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You also made the Lord angry at Taberah, Massah, and Kibroth-hattaavah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And at Kadesh-barnea the Lord sent you out with this command: ‘Go up and take over the land I have given you.’ But you rebelled against the command of the Lord your God and refused to put your trust in him or obey him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, you have been rebelling against the Lord as long as I have known you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “That is why I threw myself down before the Lord for forty days and nights—for the Lord said he would destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I prayed to the Lord and said, ‘O Sovereign Lord, do not destroy them. They are your own people. They are your special possession, whom you redeemed from Egypt by your mighty power and your strong hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please overlook the stubbornness and the awful sin of these people, and remember instead your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you destroy these people, the Egyptians will say, “The Israelites died because the Lord wasn’t able to bring them to the land he had promised to give them.” Or they might say, “He destroyed them because he hated them; he deliberately took them into the wilderness to slaughter them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they are your people and your special possession, whom you brought out of Egypt by your great strength and powerful arm.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “At that time the Lord said to me, ‘Chisel out two stone tablets like the first ones. Also make a wooden Ark—a sacred chest to store them in. Come up to me on the mountain,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will write on the tablets the same words that were on the ones you smashed. Then place the tablets in the Ark.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I made an Ark of acacia wood and cut two stone tablets like the first two. Then I went up the mountain with the tablets in my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again the Lord wrote the Ten Commandments on the tablets and gave them to me. They were the same words the Lord had spoken to you from the heart of the fire on the day you were assembled at the foot of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I turned and came down the mountain and placed the tablets in the Ark of the Covenant, which I had made, just as the Lord commanded me. And the tablets are still there in the Ark.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (The people of Israel set out from the wells of the people of Jaakan and traveled to Moserah, where Aaron died and was buried. His son Eleazar ministered as high priest in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they journeyed to Gudgodah, and from there to Jotbathah, a land with many brooks and streams.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Lord set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant, and to stand before the Lord as his ministers, and to pronounce blessings in his name. These are their duties to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why the Levites have no share of property or possession of land among the other Israelite tribes. The Lord himself is their special possession, as the Lord your God told them.)
speaker: Narrator

text: “As for me, I stayed on the mountain in the Lord’s presence for forty days and nights, as I had done the first time. And once again the Lord listened to my pleas and agreed not to destroy you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to me, ‘Get up and resume the journey, and lead the people to the land I swore to give to their ancestors, so they may take possession of it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, Israel, what does the Lord your God require of you? He requires only that you fear the Lord your God, and live in a way that pleases him, and love him and serve him with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must always obey the Lord’s commands and decrees that I am giving you today for your own good.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, the highest heavens and the earth and everything in it all belong to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet the Lord chose your ancestors as the objects of his love. And he chose you, their descendants, above all other nations, as is evident today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, change your hearts and stop being stubborn.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For the Lord your God is the God of gods and Lord of lords. He is the great God, the mighty and awesome God, who shows no partiality and cannot be bribed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ensures that orphans and widows receive justice. He shows love to the foreigners living among you and gives them food and clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you, too, must show love to foreigners, for you yourselves were once foreigners in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must fear the Lord your God and worship him and cling to him. Your oaths must be in his name alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: He alone is your God, the only one who is worthy of your praise, the one who has done these mighty miracles that you have seen with your own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your ancestors went down into Egypt, there were only seventy of them. But now the Lord your God has made you as numerous as the stars in the sky!
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must love the Lord your God and always obey his requirements, decrees, regulations, and commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep in mind that I am not talking now to your children, who have never experienced the discipline of the Lord your God or seen his greatness and his strong hand and powerful arm.
speaker: Narrator

text: They didn’t see the miraculous signs and wonders he performed in Egypt against Pharaoh and all his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: They didn’t see what the Lord did to the armies of Egypt and to their horses and chariots—how he drowned them in the Red Sea as they were chasing you. He destroyed them, and they have not recovered to this very day!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your children didn’t see how the Lord cared for you in the wilderness until you arrived here.
speaker: Narrator

text: They didn’t see what he did to Dathan and Abiram (the sons of Eliab, a descendant of Reuben) when the earth opened its mouth in the Israelite camp and swallowed them, along with their households and tents and every living thing that belonged to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have seen the Lord perform all these mighty deeds with your own eyes!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, be careful to obey every command I am giving you today, so you may have strength to go in and take over the land you are about to enter.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you obey, you will enjoy a long life in the land the Lord swore to give to your ancestors and to you, their descendants—a land flowing with milk and honey!
speaker: Narrator

text: For the land you are about to enter and take over is not like the land of Egypt from which you came, where you planted your seed and made irrigation ditches with your foot as in a vegetable garden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, the land you will soon take over is a land of hills and valleys with plenty of rain—
speaker: Narrator

text: a land that the Lord your God cares for. He watches over it through each season of the year!
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you carefully obey the commands I am giving you today, and if you love the Lord your God and serve him with all your heart and soul,
speaker: Narrator

text: then he will send the rains in their proper seasons—the early and late rains—so you can bring in your harvests of grain, new wine, and olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give you lush pastureland for your livestock, and you yourselves will have all you want to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But be careful. Don’t let your heart be deceived so that you turn away from the Lord and serve and worship other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do, the Lord’s anger will burn against you. He will shut up the sky and hold back the rain, and the ground will fail to produce its harvests. Then you will quickly die in that good land the Lord is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So commit yourselves wholeheartedly to these words of mine. Tie them to your hands and wear them on your forehead as reminders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them to your children. Talk about them when you are at home and when you are on the road, when you are going to bed and when you are getting up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write them on the doorposts of your house and on your gates,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that as long as the sky remains above the earth, you and your children may flourish in the land the Lord swore to give your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be careful to obey all these commands I am giving you. Show love to the Lord your God by walking in his ways and holding tightly to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord will drive out all the nations ahead of you, though they are much greater and stronger than you, and you will take over their land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever you set foot, that land will be yours. Your frontiers will stretch from the wilderness in the south to Lebanon in the north, and from the Euphrates River in the east to the Mediterranean Sea in the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one will be able to stand against you, for the Lord your God will cause the people to fear and dread you, as he promised, wherever you go in the whole land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, today I am giving you the choice between a blessing and a curse!
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be blessed if you obey the commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will be cursed if you reject the commands of the Lord your God and turn away from him and worship gods you have not known before.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God brings you into the land and helps you take possession of it, you must pronounce the blessing at Mount Gerizim and the curse at Mount Ebal.
speaker: Narrator

text: (These two mountains are west of the Jordan River in the land of the Canaanites who live in the Jordan Valley, near the town of Gilgal, not far from the oaks of Moreh.)
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are about to cross the Jordan River to take over the land the Lord your God is giving you. When you take that land and are living in it,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must be careful to obey all the decrees and regulations I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the decrees and regulations you must be careful to obey when you live in the land that the Lord, the God of your ancestors, is giving you. You must obey them as long as you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you drive out the nations that live there, you must destroy all the places where they worship their gods—high on the mountains, up on the hills, and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Break down their altars and smash their sacred pillars. Burn their Asherah poles and cut down their carved idols. Completely erase the names of their gods!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not worship the Lord your God in the way these pagan peoples worship their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather, you must seek the Lord your God at the place of worship he himself will choose from among all the tribes—the place where his name will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you will bring your burnt offerings, your sacrifices, your tithes, your sacred offerings, your offerings to fulfill a vow, your voluntary offerings, and your offerings of the firstborn animals of your herds and flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: There you and your families will feast in the presence of the Lord your God, and you will rejoice in all you have accomplished because the Lord your God has blessed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your pattern of worship will change. Today all of you are doing as you please,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you have not yet arrived at the place of rest, the land the Lord your God is giving you as your special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will soon cross the Jordan River and live in the land the Lord your God is giving you. When he gives you rest from all your enemies and you’re living safely in the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must bring everything I command you—your burnt offerings, your sacrifices, your tithes, your sacred offerings, and your offerings to fulfill a vow—to the designated place of worship, the place the Lord your God chooses for his name to be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must celebrate there in the presence of the Lord your God with your sons and daughters and all your servants. And remember to include the Levites who live in your towns, for they will receive no allotment of land among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to sacrifice your burnt offerings just anywhere you like.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may do so only at the place the Lord will choose within one of your tribal territories. There you must offer your burnt offerings and do everything I command you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you may butcher your animals and eat their meat in any town whenever you want. You may freely eat the animals with which the Lord your God blesses you. All of you, whether ceremonially clean or unclean, may eat that meat, just as you now eat gazelle and deer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must not consume the blood. You must pour it out on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you may not eat your offerings in your hometown—neither the tithe of your grain and new wine and olive oil, nor the firstborn of your flocks and herds, nor any offering to fulfill a vow, nor your voluntary offerings, nor your sacred offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must eat these in the presence of the Lord your God at the place he will choose. Eat them there with your children, your servants, and the Levites who live in your towns, celebrating in the presence of the Lord your God in all you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: And be very careful never to neglect the Levites as long as you live in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God expands your territory as he has promised, and you have the urge to eat meat, you may freely eat meat whenever you want.
speaker: Narrator

text: It might happen that the designated place of worship—the place the Lord your God chooses for his name to be honored—is a long way from your home. If so, you may butcher any of the cattle, sheep, or goats the Lord has given you, and you may freely eat the meat in your hometown, as I have commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone, whether ceremonially clean or unclean, may eat that meat, just as you do now with gazelle and deer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But never consume the blood, for the blood is the life, and you must not consume the lifeblood with the meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, pour out the blood on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not consume the blood, so that all may go well with you and your children after you, because you will be doing what pleases the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take your sacred gifts and your offerings given to fulfill a vow to the place the Lord chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must offer the meat and blood of your burnt offerings on the altar of the Lord your God. The blood of your other sacrifices must be poured out on the altar of the Lord your God, but you may eat the meat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful to obey all my commands, so that all will go well with you and your children after you, because you will be doing what is good and pleasing to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God goes ahead of you and destroys the nations and you drive them out and live in their land,
speaker: Narrator

text: do not fall into the trap of following their customs and worshiping their gods. Do not inquire about their gods, saying, ‘How do these nations worship their gods? I want to follow their example.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not worship the Lord your God the way the other nations worship their gods, for they perform for their gods every detestable act that the Lord hates. They even burn their sons and daughters as sacrifices to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So be careful to obey all the commands I give you. You must not add anything to them or subtract anything from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose there are prophets among you or those who dream dreams about the future, and they promise you signs or miracles,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the predicted signs or miracles occur. If they then say, ‘Come, let us worship other gods’—gods you have not known before—
speaker: Narrator

text: do not listen to them. The Lord your God is testing you to see if you truly love him with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Serve only the Lord your God and fear him alone. Obey his commands, listen to his voice, and cling to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The false prophets or visionaries who try to lead you astray must be put to death, for they encourage rebellion against the Lord your God, who redeemed you from slavery and brought you out of the land of Egypt. Since they try to lead you astray from the way the Lord your God commanded you to live, you must put them to death. In this way you will purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose someone secretly entices you—even your brother, your son or daughter, your beloved wife, or your closest friend—and says, ‘Let us go worship other gods’—gods that neither you nor your ancestors have known.
speaker: Narrator

text: They might suggest that you worship the gods of peoples who live nearby or who come from the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But do not give in or listen. Have no pity, and do not spare or protect them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must put them to death! Strike the first blow yourself, and then all the people must join in.
speaker: Narrator

text: Stone the guilty ones to death because they have tried to draw you away from the Lord your God, who rescued you from the land of Egypt, the place of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all Israel will hear about it and be afraid, and no one will act so wickedly again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you begin living in the towns the Lord your God is giving you, you may hear
speaker: Narrator

text: that scoundrels among you are leading their fellow citizens astray by saying, ‘Let us go worship other gods’—gods you have not known before.
speaker: Narrator

text: In such cases, you must examine the facts carefully. If you find that the report is true and such a detestable act has been committed among you,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must attack that town and completely destroy all its inhabitants, as well as all the livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you must pile all the plunder in the middle of the open square and burn it. Burn the entire town as a burnt offering to the Lord your God. That town must remain a ruin forever; it may never be rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep none of the plunder that has been set apart for destruction. Then the Lord will turn from his fierce anger and be merciful to you. He will have compassion on you and make you a large nation, just as he swore to your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will be merciful only if you listen to his voice and keep all his commands that I am giving you today, doing what pleases him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Since you are the people of the Lord your God, never cut yourselves or shave the hair above your foreheads in mourning for the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have been set apart as holy to the Lord your God, and he has chosen you from all the nations of the earth to be his own special treasure.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not eat any detestable animals that are ceremonially unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the animals you may eat: the ox, the sheep, the goat,
speaker: Narrator

text: the deer, the gazelle, the roe deer, the wild goat, the addax, the antelope, and the mountain sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may eat any animal that has completely split hooves and chews the cud,
speaker: Narrator

text: but if the animal doesn’t have both, it may not be eaten. So you may not eat the camel, the hare, or the hyrax. They chew the cud but do not have split hooves, so they are ceremonially unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you may not eat the pig. It has split hooves but does not chew the cud, so it is ceremonially unclean for you. You may not eat the meat of these animals or even touch their carcasses.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Of all the marine animals, you may eat whatever has both fins and scales.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may not, however, eat marine animals that do not have both fins and scales. They are ceremonially unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may eat any bird that is ceremonially clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the birds you may not eat: the griffon vulture, the bearded vulture, the black vulture,
speaker: Narrator

text: the kite, the falcon, buzzards of all kinds,
speaker: Narrator

text: ravens of all kinds,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eagle owl, the short-eared owl, the seagull, hawks of all kinds,
speaker: Narrator

text: the little owl, the great owl, the barn owl,
speaker: Narrator

text: the desert owl, the Egyptian vulture, the cormorant,
speaker: Narrator

text: the stork, herons of all kinds, the hoopoe, and the bat.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All winged insects that walk along the ground are ceremonially unclean for you and may not be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you may eat any winged bird or insect that is ceremonially clean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You must not eat anything that has died a natural death. You may give it to a foreigner living in your town, or you may sell it to a stranger. But do not eat it yourselves, for you are set apart as holy to the Lord your God.
“You must not cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must set aside a tithe of your crops—one-tenth of all the crops you harvest each year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring this tithe to the designated place of worship—the place the Lord your God chooses for his name to be honored—and eat it there in his presence. This applies to your tithes of grain, new wine, olive oil, and the firstborn males of your flocks and herds. Doing this will teach you always to fear the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now when the Lord your God blesses you with a good harvest, the place of worship he chooses for his name to be honored might be too far for you to bring the tithe.
speaker: Narrator

text: If so, you may sell the tithe portion of your crops and herds, put the money in a pouch, and go to the place the Lord your God has chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you arrive, you may use the money to buy any kind of food you want—cattle, sheep, goats, wine, or other alcoholic drink. Then feast there in the presence of the Lord your God and celebrate with your household.
speaker: Narrator

text: And do not neglect the Levites in your town, for they will receive no allotment of land among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At the end of every third year, bring the entire tithe of that year’s harvest and store it in the nearest town.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give it to the Levites, who will receive no allotment of land among you, as well as to the foreigners living among you, the orphans, and the widows in your towns, so they can eat and be satisfied. Then the Lord your God will bless you in all your work.
speaker: Narrator

text: “At the end of every seventh year you must cancel the debts of everyone who owes you money.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how it must be done. Everyone must cancel the loans they have made to their fellow Israelites. They must not demand payment from their neighbors or relatives, for the Lord’s time of release has arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text: This release from debt, however, applies only to your fellow Israelites—not to the foreigners living among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “There should be no poor among you, for the Lord your God will greatly bless you in the land he is giving you as a special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will receive this blessing if you are careful to obey all the commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will bless you as he has promised. You will lend money to many nations but will never need to borrow. You will rule many nations, but they will not rule over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if there are any poor Israelites in your towns when you arrive in the land the Lord your God is giving you, do not be hard-hearted or tightfisted toward them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, be generous and lend them whatever they need.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be mean-spirited and refuse someone a loan because the year for canceling debts is close at hand. If you refuse to make the loan and the needy person cries out to the Lord, you will be considered guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give generously to the poor, not grudgingly, for the Lord your God will bless you in everything you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will always be some in the land who are poor. That is why I am commanding you to share freely with the poor and with other Israelites in need.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a fellow Hebrew sells himself or herself to be your servant and serves you for six years, in the seventh year you must set that servant free.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you release a male servant, do not send him away empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give him a generous farewell gift from your flock, your threshing floor, and your winepress. Share with him some of the bounty with which the Lord your God has blessed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were once slaves in the land of Egypt and the Lord your God redeemed you! That is why I am giving you this command.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose your servant says, ‘I will not leave you,’ because he loves you and your family, and he has done well with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that case, take an awl and push it through his earlobe into the door. After that, he will be your servant for life. And do the same for your female servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not consider it a hardship when you release your servants. Remember that for six years they have given you services worth double the wages of hired workers, and the Lord your God will bless you in all you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must set aside for the Lord your God all the firstborn males from your flocks and herds. Do not use the firstborn of your herds to work your fields, and do not shear the firstborn of your flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, you and your family must eat these animals in the presence of the Lord your God each year at the place he chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if this firstborn animal has any defect, such as lameness or blindness, or if anything else is wrong with it, you must not sacrifice it to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, use it for food for your family in your hometown. Anyone, whether ceremonially clean or unclean, may eat it, just as anyone may eat a gazelle or deer.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must not consume the blood. You must pour it out on the ground like water.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In honor of the Lord your God, celebrate the Passover each year in the early spring, in the month of Abib, for that was the month in which the Lord your God brought you out of Egypt by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your Passover sacrifice may be from either the flock or the herd, and it must be sacrificed to the Lord your God at the designated place of worship—the place he chooses for his name to be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat it with bread made without yeast. For seven days the bread you eat must be made without yeast, as when you escaped from Egypt in such a hurry. Eat this bread—the bread of suffering—so that as long as you live you will remember the day you departed from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no yeast be found in any house throughout your land for those seven days. And when you sacrifice the Passover lamb on the evening of the first day, do not let any of the meat remain until the next morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may not sacrifice the Passover in just any of the towns that the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must offer it only at the designated place of worship—the place the Lord your God chooses for his name to be honored. Sacrifice it there in the evening as the sun goes down on the anniversary of your exodus from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Roast the lamb and eat it in the place the Lord your God chooses. Then you may go back to your tents the next morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the next six days you may not eat any bread made with yeast. On the seventh day proclaim another holy day in honor of the Lord your God, and no work may be done on that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Count off seven weeks from when you first begin to cut the grain at the time of harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then celebrate the Festival of Harvest to honor the Lord your God. Bring him a voluntary offering in proportion to the blessings you have received from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a time to celebrate before the Lord your God at the designated place of worship he will choose for his name to be honored. Celebrate with your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, the Levites from your towns, and the foreigners, orphans, and widows who live among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were once slaves in Egypt, so be careful to obey all these decrees.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must observe the Festival of Shelters for seven days at the end of the harvest season, after the grain has been threshed and the grapes have been pressed.
speaker: Narrator

text: This festival will be a happy time of celebrating with your sons and daughters, your male and female servants, and the Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows from your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you must celebrate this festival to honor the Lord your God at the place he chooses, for it is he who blesses you with bountiful harvests and gives you success in all your work. This festival will be a time of great joy for all.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Each year every man in Israel must celebrate these three festivals: the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the Festival of Harvest, and the Festival of Shelters. On each of these occasions, all men must appear before the Lord your God at the place he chooses, but they must not appear before the Lord without a gift for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All must give as they are able, according to the blessings given to them by the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Appoint judges and officials for yourselves from each of your tribes in all the towns the Lord your God is giving you. They must judge the people fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must never twist justice or show partiality. Never accept a bribe, for bribes blind the eyes of the wise and corrupt the decisions of the godly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let true justice prevail, so you may live and occupy the land that the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator
