text: “You must never set up a wooden Asherah pole beside the altar you build for the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And never set up sacred pillars for worship, for the Lord your God hates them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never sacrifice sick or defective cattle, sheep, or goats to the Lord your God, for he detests such gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you begin living in the towns the Lord your God is giving you, a man or woman among you might do evil in the sight of the Lord your God and violate the covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: For instance, they might serve other gods or worship the sun, the moon, or any of the stars—the forces of heaven—which I have strictly forbidden.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hear about it, investigate the matter thoroughly. If it is true that this detestable thing has been done in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the man or woman who has committed such an evil act must be taken to the gates of the town and stoned to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But never put a person to death on the testimony of only one witness. There must always be two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The witnesses must throw the first stones, and then all the people may join in. In this way, you will purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a case arises in a local court that is too hard for you to decide—for instance, whether someone is guilty of murder or only of manslaughter, or a difficult lawsuit, or a case involving different kinds of assault. Take such legal cases to the place the Lord your God will choose,
speaker: Narrator

text: and present them to the Levitical priests or the judge on duty at that time. They will hear the case and declare the verdict.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must carry out the verdict they announce and the sentence they prescribe at the place the Lord chooses. You must do exactly what they say.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they have interpreted the law and declared their verdict, the sentence they impose must be fully executed; do not modify it in any way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone arrogant enough to reject the verdict of the judge or of the priest who represents the Lord your God must die. In this way you will purge the evil from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then everyone else will hear about it and be afraid to act so arrogantly.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are about to enter the land the Lord your God is giving you. When you take it over and settle there, you may think, ‘We should select a king to rule over us like the other nations around us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: If this happens, be sure to select as king the man the Lord your God chooses. You must appoint a fellow Israelite; he may not be a foreigner.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The king must not build up a large stable of horses for himself or send his people to Egypt to buy horses, for the Lord has told you, ‘You must never return to Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The king must not take many wives for himself, because they will turn his heart away from the Lord. And he must not accumulate large amounts of wealth in silver and gold for himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When he sits on the throne as king, he must copy for himself this body of instruction on a scroll in the presence of the Levitical priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must always keep that copy with him and read it daily as long as he lives. That way he will learn to fear the Lord his God by obeying all the terms of these instructions and decrees.
speaker: Narrator

text: This regular reading will prevent him from becoming proud and acting as if he is above his fellow citizens. It will also prevent him from turning away from these commands in the smallest way. And it will ensure that he and his descendants will reign for many generations in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember that the Levitical priests—that is, the whole of the tribe of Levi—will receive no allotment of land among the other tribes in Israel. Instead, the priests and Levites will eat from the special gifts given to the Lord, for that is their share.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will have no land of their own among the Israelites. The Lord himself is their special possession, just as he promised them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the parts the priests may claim as their share from the cattle, sheep, and goats that the people bring as offerings: the shoulder, the cheeks, and the stomach.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must also give to the priests the first share of the grain, the new wine, the olive oil, and the wool at shearing time.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God chose the tribe of Levi out of all your tribes to minister in the Lord’s name forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a Levite chooses to move from his town in Israel, wherever he is living, to the place the Lord chooses for worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: He may minister there in the name of the Lord his God, just like all his fellow Levites who are serving the Lord there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He may eat his share of the sacrifices and offerings, even if he also receives support from his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter the land the Lord your God is giving you, be very careful not to imitate the detestable customs of the nations living there.
speaker: Narrator

text: For example, never sacrifice your son or daughter as a burnt offering. And do not let your people practice fortune-telling, or use sorcery, or interpret omens, or engage in witchcraft,
speaker: Narrator

text: or cast spells, or function as mediums or psychics, or call forth the spirits of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who does these things is detestable to the Lord. It is because the other nations have done these detestable things that the Lord your God will drive them out ahead of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must be blameless before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The nations you are about to displace consult sorcerers and fortune-tellers, but the Lord your God forbids you to do such things.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses continued, “The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your fellow Israelites. You must listen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this is what you yourselves requested of the Lord your God when you were assembled at Mount Sinai. You said, ‘Don’t let us hear the voice of the Lord our God anymore or see this blazing fire, for we will die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Lord said to me, ‘What they have said is right.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will raise up a prophet like you from among their fellow Israelites. I will put my words in his mouth, and he will tell the people everything I command him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will personally deal with anyone who will not listen to the messages the prophet proclaims on my behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: But any prophet who falsely claims to speak in my name or who speaks in the name of another god must die.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you may wonder, ‘How will we know whether or not a prophecy is from the Lord?’
speaker: Narrator

text: If the prophet speaks in the Lord’s name but his prediction does not happen or come true, you will know that the Lord did not give that message. That prophet has spoken without my authority and need not be feared.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord your God destroys the nations whose land he is giving you, you will take over their land and settle in their towns and homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you must set apart three cities of refuge in the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Survey the territory, and divide the land the Lord your God is giving you into three districts, with one of these cities in each district. Then anyone who has killed someone can flee to one of the cities of refuge for safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone kills another person unintentionally, without previous hostility, the slayer may flee to any of these cities to live in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: For example, suppose someone goes into the forest with a neighbor to cut wood. And suppose one of them swings an ax to chop down a tree, and the ax head flies off the handle, killing the other person. In such cases, the slayer may flee to one of the cities of refuge to live in safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the distance to the nearest city of refuge is too far, an enraged avenger might be able to chase down and kill the person who caused the death. Then the slayer would die unfairly, since he had never shown hostility toward the person who died.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I am commanding you to set aside three cities of refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And if the Lord your God enlarges your territory, as he swore to your ancestors, and gives you all the land he promised them,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must designate three additional cities of refuge. (He will give you this land if you are careful to obey all the commands I have given you—if you always love the Lord your God and walk in his ways.)
speaker: Narrator

text: That way you will prevent the death of innocent people in the land the Lord your God is giving you as your special possession. You will not be held responsible for the death of innocent people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose someone is hostile toward a neighbor and deliberately ambushes and murders him and then flees to one of the cities of refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that case, the elders of the murderer’s hometown must send agents to the city of refuge to bring him back and hand him over to the dead person’s avenger to be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not feel sorry for that murderer! Purge from Israel the guilt of murdering innocent people; then all will go well with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you arrive in the land the Lord your God is giving you as your special possession, you must never steal anyone’s land by moving the boundary markers your ancestors set up to mark their property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not convict anyone of a crime on the testimony of only one witness. The facts of the case must be established by the testimony of two or three witnesses.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a malicious witness comes forward and accuses someone of a crime,
speaker: Narrator

text: then both the accuser and accused must appear before the Lord by coming to the priests and judges in office at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The judges must investigate the case thoroughly. If the accuser has brought false charges against his fellow Israelite,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must impose on the accuser the sentence he intended for the other person. In this way, you will purge such evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the rest of the people will hear about it and be afraid to do such an evil thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must show no pity for the guilty! Your rule should be life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you go out to fight your enemies and you face horses and chariots and an army greater than your own, do not be afraid. The Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, is with you!
speaker: Narrator

text: When you prepare for battle, the priest must come forward to speak to the troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will say to them, ‘Listen to me, all you men of Israel! Do not be afraid as you go out to fight your enemies today! Do not lose heart or panic or tremble before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord your God is going with you! He will fight for you against your enemies, and he will give you victory!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the officers of the army must address the troops and say, ‘Has anyone here just built a new house but not yet dedicated it? If so, you may go home! You might be killed in the battle, and someone else would dedicate your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has anyone here just planted a vineyard but not yet eaten any of its fruit? If so, you may go home! You might die in battle, and someone else would eat the first fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has anyone here just become engaged to a woman but not yet married her? Well, you may go home and get married! You might die in the battle, and someone else would marry her.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the officers will also say, ‘Is anyone here afraid or worried? If you are, you may go home before you frighten anyone else.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When the officers have finished speaking to their troops, they will appoint the unit commanders.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As you approach a town to attack it, you must first offer its people terms for peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they accept your terms and open the gates to you, then all the people inside will serve you in forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if they refuse to make peace and prepare to fight, you must attack the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord your God hands the town over to you, use your swords to kill every man in the town.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you may keep for yourselves all the women, children, livestock, and other plunder. You may enjoy the plunder from your enemies that the Lord your God has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But these instructions apply only to distant towns, not to the towns of the nations in the land you will enter.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those towns that the Lord your God is giving you as a special possession, destroy every living thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must completely destroy the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, just as the Lord your God has commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: This will prevent the people of the land from teaching you to imitate their detestable customs in the worship of their gods, which would cause you to sin deeply against the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you are attacking a town and the war drags on, you must not cut down the trees with your axes. You may eat the fruit, but do not cut down the trees. Are the trees your enemies, that you should attack them?
speaker: Narrator

text: You may only cut down trees that you know are not valuable for food. Use them to make the equipment you need to attack the enemy town until it falls.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you are in the land the Lord your God is giving you, someone may be found murdered in a field, and you don’t know who committed the murder.
speaker: Narrator

text: In such a case, your elders and judges must measure the distance from the site of the crime to the nearby towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the nearest town has been determined, that town’s elders must select from the herd a heifer that has never been trained or yoked to a plow.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must lead it down to a valley that has not been plowed or planted and that has a stream running through it. There in the valley they must break the heifer’s neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Levitical priests must step forward, for the Lord your God has chosen them to minister before him and to pronounce blessings in the Lord’s name. They are to decide all legal and criminal cases.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The elders of the town must wash their hands over the heifer whose neck was broken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they must say, ‘Our hands did not shed this person’s blood, nor did we see it happen.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, forgive your people Israel whom you have redeemed. Do not charge your people with the guilt of murdering an innocent person.’ Then they will be absolved of the guilt of this person’s blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: By following these instructions, you will do what is right in the Lord’s sight and will cleanse the guilt of murder from your community.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose you go out to war against your enemies and the Lord your God hands them over to you, and you take some of them as captives.
speaker: Narrator

text: And suppose you see among the captives a beautiful woman, and you are attracted to her and want to marry her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this happens, you may take her to your home, where she must shave her head, cut her nails,
speaker: Narrator

text: and change the clothes she was wearing when she was captured. She will stay in your home, but let her mourn for her father and mother for a full month. Then you may marry her, and you will be her husband and she will be your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you marry her and she does not please you, you must let her go free. You may not sell her or treat her as a slave, for you have humiliated her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man has two wives, but he loves one and not the other, and both have given him sons. And suppose the firstborn son is the son of the wife he does not love.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the man divides his inheritance, he may not give the larger inheritance to his younger son, the son of the wife he loves, as if he were the firstborn son.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must recognize the rights of his oldest son, the son of the wife he does not love, by giving him a double portion. He is the first son of his father’s virility, and the rights of the firstborn belong to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man has a stubborn and rebellious son who will not obey his father or mother, even though they discipline him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In such a case, the father and mother must take the son to the elders as they hold court at the town gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: The parents must say to the elders, ‘This son of ours is stubborn and rebellious and refuses to obey. He is a glutton and a drunkard.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the men of his town must stone him to death. In this way, you will purge this evil from among you, and all Israel will hear about it and be afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone has committed a crime worthy of death and is executed and hung on a tree,
speaker: Narrator

text: the body must not remain hanging from the tree overnight. You must bury the body that same day, for anyone who is hung is cursed in the sight of God. In this way, you will prevent the defilement of the land the Lord your God is giving you as your special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you see your neighbor’s ox or sheep or goat wandering away, don’t ignore your responsibility. Take it back to its owner.
speaker: Narrator

text: If its owner does not live nearby or you don’t know who the owner is, take it to your place and keep it until the owner comes looking for it. Then you must return it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do the same if you find your neighbor’s donkey, clothing, or anything else your neighbor loses. Don’t ignore your responsibility.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you see that your neighbor’s donkey or ox has collapsed on the road, do not look the other way. Go and help your neighbor get it back on its feet!
speaker: Narrator

text: “A woman must not put on men’s clothing, and a man must not wear women’s clothing. Anyone who does this is detestable in the sight of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you happen to find a bird’s nest in a tree or on the ground, and there are young ones or eggs in it with the mother sitting in the nest, do not take the mother with the young.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may take the young, but let the mother go, so that you may prosper and enjoy a long life.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you build a new house, you must build a railing around the edge of its flat roof. That way you will not be considered guilty of murder if someone falls from the roof.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not plant any other crop between the rows of your vineyard. If you do, you are forbidden to use either the grapes from the vineyard or the other crop.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not plow with an ox and a donkey harnessed together.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not wear clothing made of wool and linen woven together.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must put four tassels on the hem of the cloak with which you cover yourself—on the front, back, and sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man marries a woman, but after sleeping with her, he turns against her
speaker: Narrator

text: and publicly accuses her of shameful conduct, saying, ‘When I married this woman, I discovered she was not a virgin.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman’s father and mother must bring the proof of her virginity to the elders as they hold court at the town gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Her father must say to them, ‘I gave my daughter to this man to be his wife, and now he has turned against her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has accused her of shameful conduct, saying, “I discovered that your daughter was not a virgin.” But here is the proof of my daughter’s virginity.’ Then they must spread her bed sheet before the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders must then take the man and punish him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must also fine him 100 pieces of silver, which he must pay to the woman’s father because he publicly accused a virgin of Israel of shameful conduct. The woman will then remain the man’s wife, and he may never divorce her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But suppose the man’s accusations are true, and he can show that she was not a virgin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman must be taken to the door of her father’s home, and there the men of the town must stone her to death, for she has committed a disgraceful crime in Israel by being promiscuous while living in her parents’ home. In this way, you will purge this evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man is discovered committing adultery, both he and the woman must die. In this way, you will purge Israel of such evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man meets a young woman, a virgin who is engaged to be married, and he has sexual intercourse with her. If this happens within a town,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must take both of them to the gates of that town and stone them to death. The woman is guilty because she did not scream for help. The man must die because he violated another man’s wife. In this way, you will purge this evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if the man meets the engaged woman out in the country, and he rapes her, then only the man must die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do nothing to the young woman; she has committed no crime worthy of death. She is as innocent as a murder victim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since the man raped her out in the country, it must be assumed that she screamed, but there was no one to rescue her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man has intercourse with a young woman who is a virgin but is not engaged to be married. If they are discovered,
speaker: Narrator

text: he must pay her father fifty pieces of silver. Then he must marry the young woman because he violated her, and he may never divorce her as long as he lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A man must not marry his father’s former wife, for this would violate his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man’s testicles are crushed or his penis is cut off, he may not be admitted to the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a person is illegitimate by birth, neither he nor his descendants for ten generations may be admitted to the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No Ammonite or Moabite or any of their descendants for ten generations may be admitted to the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: These nations did not welcome you with food and water when you came out of Egypt. Instead, they hired Balaam son of Beor from Pethor in distant Aram-naharaim to curse you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord your God refused to listen to Balaam. He turned the intended curse into a blessing because the Lord your God loves you.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as you live, you must never promote the welfare and prosperity of the Ammonites or Moabites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not detest the Edomites or the Egyptians, because the Edomites are your relatives and you lived as foreigners among the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third generation of Edomites and Egyptians may enter the assembly of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you go to war against your enemies, be sure to stay away from anything that is impure.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Any man who becomes ceremonially defiled because of a nocturnal emission must leave the camp and stay away all day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Toward evening he must bathe himself, and at sunset he may return to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must have a designated area outside the camp where you can go to relieve yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of you must have a spade as part of your equipment. Whenever you relieve yourself, dig a hole with the spade and cover the excrement.
speaker: Narrator

text: The camp must be holy, for the Lord your God moves around in your camp to protect you and to defeat your enemies. He must not see any shameful thing among you, or he will turn away from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If slaves should escape from their masters and take refuge with you, you must not hand them over to their masters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them live among you in any town they choose, and do not oppress them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No Israelite, whether man or woman, may become a temple prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you are bringing an offering to fulfill a vow, you must not bring to the house of the Lord your God any offering from the earnings of a prostitute, whether a man or a woman, for both are detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not charge interest on the loans you make to a fellow Israelite, whether you loan money, or food, or anything else.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may charge interest to foreigners, but you may not charge interest to Israelites, so that the Lord your God may bless you in everything you do in the land you are about to enter and occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you make a vow to the Lord your God, be prompt in fulfilling whatever you promised him. For the Lord your God demands that you promptly fulfill all your vows, or you will be guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, it is not a sin to refrain from making a vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: But once you have voluntarily made a vow, be careful to fulfill your promise to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter your neighbor’s vineyard, you may eat your fill of grapes, but you must not carry any away in a basket.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when you enter your neighbor’s field of grain, you may pluck the heads of grain with your hand, but you must not harvest it with a sickle.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose a man marries a woman but she does not please him. Having discovered something wrong with her, he writes a document of divorce, hands it to her, and sends her away from his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she leaves his house, she is free to marry another man.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the second husband also turns against her, writes a document of divorce, hands it to her, and sends her away, or if he dies,
speaker: Narrator

text: the first husband may not marry her again, for she has been defiled. That would be detestable to the Lord. You must not bring guilt upon the land the Lord your God is giving you as a special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A newly married man must not be drafted into the army or be given any other official responsibilities. He must be free to spend one year at home, bringing happiness to the wife he has married.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is wrong to take a set of millstones, or even just the upper millstone, as security for a loan, for the owner uses it to make a living.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone kidnaps a fellow Israelite and treats him as a slave or sells him, the kidnapper must die. In this way, you will purge the evil from among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In all cases involving serious skin diseases, be careful to follow the instructions of the Levitical priests; obey all the commands I have given them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember what the Lord your God did to Miriam as you were coming from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you lend anything to your neighbor, do not enter his house to pick up the item he is giving as security.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must wait outside while he goes in and brings it out to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your neighbor is poor and gives you his cloak as security for a loan, do not keep the cloak overnight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Return the cloak to its owner by sunset so he can stay warm through the night and bless you, and the Lord your God will count you as righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never take advantage of poor and destitute laborers, whether they are fellow Israelites or foreigners living in your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must pay them their wages each day before sunset because they are poor and are counting on it. If you don’t, they might cry out to the Lord against you, and it would be counted against you as sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Parents must not be put to death for the sins of their children, nor children for the sins of their parents. Those deserving to die must be put to death for their own crimes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “True justice must be given to foreigners living among you and to orphans, and you must never accept a widow’s garment as security for her debt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Always remember that you were slaves in Egypt and that the Lord your God redeemed you from your slavery. That is why I have given you this command.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you are harvesting your crops and forget to bring in a bundle of grain from your field, don’t go back to get it. Leave it for the foreigners, orphans, and widows. Then the Lord your God will bless you in all you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you beat the olives from your olive trees, don’t go over the boughs twice. Leave the remaining olives for the foreigners, orphans, and widows.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you gather the grapes in your vineyard, don’t glean the vines after they are picked. Leave the remaining grapes for the foreigners, orphans, and widows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that you were slaves in the land of Egypt. That is why I am giving you this command.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Suppose two people take a dispute to court, and the judges declare that one is right and the other is wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the person in the wrong is sentenced to be flogged, the judge must command him to lie down and be beaten in his presence with the number of lashes appropriate to the crime.
speaker: Narrator

text: But never give more than forty lashes; more than forty lashes would publicly humiliate your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not muzzle an ox to keep it from eating as it treads out the grain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If two brothers are living together on the same property and one of them dies without a son, his widow may not be married to anyone from outside the family. Instead, her husband’s brother should marry her and have intercourse with her to fulfill the duties of a brother-in-law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first son she bears to him will be considered the son of the dead brother, so that his name will not be forgotten in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if the man refuses to marry his brother’s widow, she must go to the town gate and say to the elders assembled there, ‘My husband’s brother refuses to preserve his brother’s name in Israel—he refuses to fulfill the duties of a brother-in-law by marrying me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of the town will then summon him and talk with him. If he still refuses and says, ‘I don’t want to marry her,’
speaker: Narrator

text: the widow must walk over to him in the presence of the elders, pull his sandal from his foot, and spit in his face. Then she must declare, ‘This is what happens to a man who refuses to provide his brother with children.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Ever afterward in Israel his family will be referred to as ‘the family of the man whose sandal was pulled off’!
speaker: Narrator

text: “If two Israelite men get into a fight and the wife of one tries to rescue her husband by grabbing the testicles of the other man,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must cut off her hand. Show her no pity.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must use accurate scales when you weigh out merchandise,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you must use full and honest measures.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yes, always use honest weights and measures, so that you may enjoy a long life in the land the Lord your God is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who cheat with dishonest weights and measures are detestable to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never forget what the Amalekites did to you as you came from Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: They attacked you when you were exhausted and weary, and they struck down those who were straggling behind. They had no fear of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, when the Lord your God has given you rest from all your enemies in the land he is giving you as a special possession, you must destroy the Amalekites and erase their memory from under heaven. Never forget this!
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you enter the land the Lord your God is giving you as a special possession and you have conquered it and settled there,
speaker: Narrator

text: put some of the first produce from each crop you harvest into a basket and bring it to the designated place of worship—the place the Lord your God chooses for his name to be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to the priest in charge at that time and say to him, ‘With this gift I acknowledge to the Lord your God that I have entered the land he swore to our ancestors he would give us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will then take the basket from your hand and set it before the altar of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must then say in the presence of the Lord your God, ‘My ancestor Jacob was a wandering Aramean who went to live as a foreigner in Egypt. His family arrived few in number, but in Egypt they became a large and mighty nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Egyptians oppressed and humiliated us by making us their slaves,
speaker: Narrator

text: we cried out to the Lord, the God of our ancestors. He heard our cries and saw our hardship, toil, and oppression.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a strong hand and powerful arm, with overwhelming terror, and with miraculous signs and wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought us to this place and gave us this land flowing with milk and honey!
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, O Lord, I have brought you the first portion of the harvest you have given me from the ground.’ Then place the produce before the Lord your God, and bow to the ground in worship before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward you may go and celebrate because of all the good things the Lord your God has given to you and your household. Remember to include the Levites and the foreigners living among you in the celebration.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every third year you must offer a special tithe of your crops. In this year of the special tithe you must give your tithes to the Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows, so that they will have enough to eat in your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you must declare in the presence of the Lord your God, ‘I have taken the sacred gift from my house and have given it to the Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows, just as you commanded me. I have not violated or forgotten any of your commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not eaten any of it while in mourning; I have not handled it while I was ceremonially unclean; and I have not offered any of it to the dead. I have obeyed the Lord my God and have done everything you commanded me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look down from your holy dwelling place in heaven and bless your people Israel and the land you swore to our ancestors to give us—a land flowing with milk and honey.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Today the Lord your God has commanded you to obey all these decrees and regulations. So be careful to obey them wholeheartedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have declared today that the Lord is your God. And you have promised to walk in his ways, and to obey his decrees, commands, and regulations, and to do everything he tells you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has declared today that you are his people, his own special treasure, just as he promised, and that you must obey all his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if you do, he will set you high above all the other nations he has made. Then you will receive praise, honor, and renown. You will be a nation that is holy to the Lord your God, just as he promised.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the leaders of Israel gave this charge to the people: “Obey all these commands that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you cross the Jordan River and enter the land the Lord your God is giving you, set up some large stones and coat them with plaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Write this whole body of instruction on them when you cross the river to enter the land the Lord your God is giving you—a land flowing with milk and honey, just as the Lord, the God of your ancestors, promised you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you cross the Jordan, set up these stones at Mount Ebal and coat them with plaster, as I am commanding you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then build an altar there to the Lord your God, using natural, uncut stones. You must not shape the stones with an iron tool.
speaker: Narrator

text: Build the altar of uncut stones, and use it to offer burnt offerings to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also sacrifice peace offerings on it, and celebrate by feasting there before the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must clearly write all these instructions on the stones coated with plaster.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and the Levitical priests addressed all Israel as follows: “O Israel, be quiet and listen! Today you have become the people of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must obey the Lord your God by keeping all these commands and decrees that I am giving you today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Moses also gave this charge to the people:
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you cross the Jordan River, the tribes of Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph, and Benjamin must stand on Mount Gerizim to proclaim a blessing over the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the tribes of Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan, and Naphtali must stand on Mount Ebal to proclaim a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the Levites will shout to all the people of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who carves or casts an idol and secretly sets it up. These idols, the work of craftsmen, are detestable to the Lord.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who dishonors father or mother.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who steals property from a neighbor by moving a boundary marker.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who leads a blind person astray on the road.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who denies justice to foreigners, orphans, or widows.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who has sexual intercourse with one of his father’s wives, for he has violated his father.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who has sexual intercourse with an animal.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who has sexual intercourse with his sister, whether she is the daughter of his father or his mother.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who has sexual intercourse with his mother-in-law.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who attacks a neighbor in secret.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who accepts payment to kill an innocent person.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Cursed is anyone who does not affirm and obey the terms of these instructions.’
And all the people will reply, ‘Amen.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you fully obey the Lord your God and carefully keep all his commands that I am giving you today, the Lord your God will set you high above all the nations of the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will experience all these blessings if you obey the Lord your God:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your towns and your fields
    will be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your children and your crops
    will be blessed.
The offspring of your herds and flocks
    will be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your fruit baskets and breadboards
    will be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherever you go and whatever you do,
    you will be blessed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will conquer your enemies when they attack you. They will attack you from one direction, but they will scatter from you in seven!
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will guarantee a blessing on everything you do and will fill your storehouses with grain. The Lord your God will bless you in the land he is giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you obey the commands of the Lord your God and walk in his ways, the Lord will establish you as his holy people as he swore he would do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the nations of the world will see that you are a people claimed by the Lord, and they will stand in awe of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will give you prosperity in the land he swore to your ancestors to give you, blessing you with many children, numerous livestock, and abundant crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will send rain at the proper time from his rich treasury in the heavens and will bless all the work you do. You will lend to many nations, but you will never need to borrow from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you listen to these commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you today, and if you carefully obey them, the Lord will make you the head and not the tail, and you will always be on top and never at the bottom.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not turn away from any of the commands I am giving you today, nor follow after other gods and worship them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you refuse to listen to the Lord your God and do not obey all the commands and decrees I am giving you today, all these curses will come and overwhelm you:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your towns and your fields
    will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your fruit baskets and breadboards
    will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your children and your crops
    will be cursed.
The offspring of your herds and flocks
    will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherever you go and whatever you do,
    you will be cursed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord himself will send on you curses, confusion, and frustration in everything you do, until at last you are completely destroyed for doing evil and abandoning me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will afflict you with diseases until none of you are left in the land you are about to enter and occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike you with wasting diseases, fever, and inflammation, with scorching heat and drought, and with blight and mildew. These disasters will pursue you until you die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The skies above will be as unyielding as bronze, and the earth beneath will be as hard as iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will change the rain that falls on your land into powder, and dust will pour down from the sky until you are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will cause you to be defeated by your enemies. You will attack your enemies from one direction, but you will scatter from them in seven! You will be an object of horror to all the kingdoms of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your corpses will be food for all the scavenging birds and wild animals, and no one will be there to chase them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will afflict you with the boils of Egypt and with tumors, scurvy, and the itch, from which you cannot be cured.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will strike you with madness, blindness, and panic.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will grope around in broad daylight like a blind person groping in the darkness, but you will not find your way. You will be oppressed and robbed continually, and no one will come to save you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You will be engaged to a woman, but another man will sleep with her. You will build a house, but someone else will live in it. You will plant a vineyard, but you will never enjoy its fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your ox will be butchered before your eyes, but you will not eat a single bite of the meat. Your donkey will be taken from you, never to be returned. Your sheep and goats will be given to your enemies, and no one will be there to help you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will watch as your sons and daughters are taken away as slaves. Your heart will break for them, but you won’t be able to help them.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foreign nation you have never heard about will eat the crops you worked so hard to grow. You will suffer under constant oppression and harsh treatment.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will go mad because of all the tragedy you see around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will cover your knees and legs with incurable boils. In fact, you will be covered from head to foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will exile you and your king to a nation unknown to you and your ancestors. There in exile you will worship gods of wood and stone!
speaker: Narrator

text: You will become an object of horror, ridicule, and mockery among all the nations to which the Lord sends you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You will plant much but harvest little, for locusts will eat your crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will plant vineyards and care for them, but you will not drink the wine or eat the grapes, for worms will destroy the vines.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will grow olive trees throughout your land, but you will never use the olive oil, for the fruit will drop before it ripens.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will have sons and daughters, but you will lose them, for they will be led away into captivity.
speaker: Narrator

text: Swarms of insects will destroy your trees and crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The foreigners living among you will become stronger and stronger, while you become weaker and weaker.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will lend money to you, but you will not lend to them. They will be the head, and you will be the tail!
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you refuse to listen to the Lord your God and to obey the commands and decrees he has given you, all these curses will pursue and overtake you until you are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: These horrors will serve as a sign and warning among you and your descendants forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do not serve the Lord your God with joy and enthusiasm for the abundant benefits you have received,
speaker: Narrator

text: you will serve your enemies whom the Lord will send against you. You will be left hungry, thirsty, naked, and lacking in everything. The Lord will put an iron yoke on your neck, oppressing you harshly until he has destroyed you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will bring a distant nation against you from the end of the earth, and it will swoop down on you like a vulture. It is a nation whose language you do not understand,
speaker: Narrator

text: a fierce and heartless nation that shows no respect for the old and no pity for the young.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its armies will devour your livestock and crops, and you will be destroyed. They will leave you no grain, new wine, olive oil, calves, or lambs, and you will starve to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will attack your cities until all the fortified walls in your land—the walls you trusted to protect you—are knocked down. They will attack all the towns in the land the Lord your God has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The siege and terrible distress of the enemy’s attack will be so severe that you will eat the flesh of your own sons and daughters, whom the Lord your God has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The most tenderhearted man among you will have no compassion for his own brother, his beloved wife, and his surviving children.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will refuse to share with them the flesh he is devouring—the flesh of one of his own children—because he has nothing else to eat during the siege and terrible distress that your enemy will inflict on all your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The most tender and delicate woman among you—so delicate she would not so much as touch the ground with her foot—will be selfish toward the husband she loves and toward her own son or daughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: She will hide from them the afterbirth and the new baby she has borne, so that she herself can secretly eat them. She will have nothing else to eat during the siege and terrible distress that your enemy will inflict on all your towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you refuse to obey all the words of instruction that are written in this book, and if you do not fear the glorious and awesome name of the Lord your God,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord will overwhelm you and your children with indescribable plagues. These plagues will be intense and without relief, making you miserable and unbearably sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will afflict you with all the diseases of Egypt that you feared so much, and you will have no relief.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will afflict you with every sickness and plague there is, even those not mentioned in this Book of Instruction, until you are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Though you become as numerous as the stars in the sky, few of you will be left because you would not listen to the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Just as the Lord has found great pleasure in causing you to prosper and multiply, the Lord will find pleasure in destroying you. You will be torn from the land you are about to enter and occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will scatter you among all the nations from one end of the earth to the other. There you will worship foreign gods that neither you nor your ancestors have known, gods made of wood and stone!
speaker: Narrator

text: There among those nations you will find no peace or place to rest. And the Lord will cause your heart to tremble, your eyesight to fail, and your soul to despair.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your life will constantly hang in the balance. You will live night and day in fear, unsure if you will survive.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning you will say, ‘If only it were night!’ And in the evening you will say, ‘If only it were morning!’ For you will be terrified by the awful horrors you see around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord will send you back to Egypt in ships, to a destination I promised you would never see again. There you will offer to sell yourselves to your enemies as slaves, but no one will buy you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the terms of the covenant the Lord commanded Moses to make with the Israelites while they were in the land of Moab, in addition to the covenant he had made with them at Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses summoned all the Israelites and said to them, “You have seen with your own eyes everything the Lord did in the land of Egypt to Pharaoh and to all his servants and to his whole country—
speaker: Narrator

text: all the great tests of strength, the miraculous signs, and the amazing wonders.
speaker: Narrator

text: But to this day the Lord has not given you minds that understand, nor eyes that see, nor ears that hear!
speaker: Narrator

text: For forty years I led you through the wilderness, yet your clothes and sandals did not wear out.
speaker: Narrator

text: You ate no bread and drank no wine or other alcoholic drink, but he provided for you so you would know that he is the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When we came here, King Sihon of Heshbon and King Og of Bashan came out to fight against us, but we defeated them.
speaker: Narrator

text: We took their land and gave it to the tribes of Reuben and Gad and to the half-tribe of Manasseh as their grant of land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore, obey the terms of this covenant so that you will prosper in everything you do.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of you—tribal leaders, elders, officers, all the men of Israel—are standing today in the presence of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your little ones and your wives are with you, as well as the foreigners living among you who chop your wood and carry your water.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are standing here today to enter into the covenant of the Lord your God. The Lord is making this covenant, including the curses.
speaker: Narrator

text: By entering into the covenant today, he will establish you as his people and confirm that he is your God, just as he promised you and as he swore to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But you are not the only ones with whom I am making this covenant with its curses.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am making this covenant both with you who stand here today in the presence of the Lord our God, and also with the future generations who are not standing here today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You remember how we lived in the land of Egypt and how we traveled through the lands of enemy nations as we left.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have seen their detestable practices and their idols made of wood, stone, silver, and gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am making this covenant with you so that no one among you—no man, woman, clan, or tribe—will turn away from the Lord our God to worship these gods of other nations, and so that no root among you bears bitter and poisonous fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Those who hear the warnings of this curse should not congratulate themselves, thinking, ‘I am safe, even though I am following the desires of my own stubborn heart.’ This would lead to utter ruin!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will never pardon such people. Instead his anger and jealousy will burn against them. All the curses written in this book will come down on them, and the Lord will erase their names from under heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will separate them from all the tribes of Israel, to pour out on them all the curses of the covenant recorded in this Book of Instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the generations to come, both your own descendants and the foreigners who come from distant lands, will see the devastation of the land and the diseases the Lord inflicts on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will exclaim, ‘The whole land is devastated by sulfur and salt. It is a wasteland with nothing planted and nothing growing, not even a blade of grass. It is like the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim, which the Lord destroyed in his intense anger.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And all the surrounding nations will ask, ‘Why has the Lord done this to this land? Why was he so angry?’
speaker: Narrator

text: “And the answer will be, ‘This happened because the people of the land abandoned the covenant that the Lord, the God of their ancestors, made with them when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, they turned away to serve and worship gods they had not known before, gods that were not from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why the Lord’s anger has burned against this land, bringing down on it every curse recorded in this book.
speaker: Narrator

text: In great anger and fury the Lord uprooted his people from their land and banished them to another land, where they still live today!’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord our God has secrets known to no one. We are not accountable for them, but we and our children are accountable forever for all that he has revealed to us, so that we may obey all the terms of these instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the future, when you experience all these blessings and curses I have listed for you, and when you are living among the nations to which the Lord your God has exiled you, take to heart all these instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: If at that time you and your children return to the Lord your God, and if you obey with all your heart and all your soul all the commands I have given you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the Lord your God will restore your fortunes. He will have mercy on you and gather you back from all the nations where he has scattered you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even though you are banished to the ends of the earth, the Lord your God will gather you from there and bring you back again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will return you to the land that belonged to your ancestors, and you will possess that land again. Then he will make you even more prosperous and numerous than your ancestors!
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will change your heart and the hearts of all your descendants, so that you will love him with all your heart and soul and so you may live!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will inflict all these curses on your enemies and on those who hate and persecute you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will again obey the Lord and keep all his commands that I am giving you today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God will then make you successful in everything you do. He will give you many children and numerous livestock, and he will cause your fields to produce abundant harvests, for the Lord will again delight in being good to you as he was to your ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord your God will delight in you if you obey his voice and keep the commands and decrees written in this Book of Instruction, and if you turn to the Lord your God with all your heart and soul.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This command I am giving you today is not too difficult for you, and it is not beyond your reach.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not kept in heaven, so distant that you must ask, ‘Who will go up to heaven and bring it down so we can hear it and obey?’
speaker: Narrator

text: It is not kept beyond the sea, so far away that you must ask, ‘Who will cross the sea to bring it to us so we can hear it and obey?’
speaker: Narrator

text: No, the message is very close at hand; it is on your lips and in your heart so that you can obey it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now listen! Today I am giving you a choice between life and death, between prosperity and disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I command you this day to love the Lord your God and to keep his commands, decrees, and regulations by walking in his ways. If you do this, you will live and multiply, and the Lord your God will bless you and the land you are about to enter and occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if your heart turns away and you refuse to listen, and if you are drawn away to serve and worship other gods,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I warn you now that you will certainly be destroyed. You will not live a long, good life in the land you are crossing the Jordan to occupy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Today I have given you the choice between life and death, between blessings and curses. Now I call on heaven and earth to witness the choice you make. Oh, that you would choose life, so that you and your descendants might live!
speaker: Narrator

text: You can make this choice by loving the Lord your God, obeying him, and committing yourself firmly to him. This is the key to your life. And if you love and obey the Lord, you will live long in the land the Lord swore to give your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had finished giving these instructions to all the people of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said, “I am now 120 years old, and I am no longer able to lead you. The Lord has told me, ‘You will not cross the Jordan River.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord your God himself will cross over ahead of you. He will destroy the nations living there, and you will take possession of their land. Joshua will lead you across the river, just as the Lord promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will destroy the nations living in the land, just as he destroyed Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will hand over to you the people who live there, and you must deal with them as I have commanded you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So be strong and courageous! Do not be afraid and do not panic before them. For the Lord your God will personally go ahead of you. He will neither fail you nor abandon you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses called for Joshua, and as all Israel watched, he said to him, “Be strong and courageous! For you will lead these people into the land that the Lord swore to their ancestors he would give them. You are the one who will divide it among them as their grants of land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be afraid or discouraged, for the Lord will personally go ahead of you. He will be with you; he will neither fail you nor abandon you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses wrote this entire body of instruction in a book and gave it to the priests, who carried the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant, and to the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses gave them this command: “At the end of every seventh year, the Year of Release, during the Festival of Shelters,
speaker: Narrator

text: you must read this Book of Instruction to all the people of Israel when they assemble before the Lord your God at the place he chooses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Call them all together—men, women, children, and the foreigners living in your towns—so they may hear this Book of Instruction and learn to fear the Lord your God and carefully obey all the terms of these instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this so that your children who have not known these instructions will hear them and will learn to fear the Lord your God. Do this as long as you live in the land you are crossing the Jordan to occupy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “The time has come for you to die. Call Joshua and present yourselves at the Tabernacle, so that I may commission him there.” So Moses and Joshua went and presented themselves at the Tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord appeared to them in a pillar of cloud that stood at the entrance to the sacred tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “You are about to die and join your ancestors. After you are gone, these people will begin to worship foreign gods, the gods of the land where they are going. They will abandon me and break my covenant that I have made with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then my anger will blaze forth against them. I will abandon them, hiding my face from them, and they will be devoured. Terrible trouble will come down on them, and on that day they will say, ‘These disasters have come down on us because God is no longer among us!’
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time I will hide my face from them on account of all the evil they commit by worshiping other gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So write down the words of this song, and teach it to the people of Israel. Help them learn it, so it may serve as a witness for me against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will bring them into the land I swore to give their ancestors—a land flowing with milk and honey. There they will become prosperous, eat all the food they want, and become fat. But they will begin to worship other gods; they will despise me and break my covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when great disasters come down on them, this song will stand as evidence against them, for it will never be forgotten by their descendants. I know the intentions of these people, even now before they have entered the land I swore to give them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So that very day Moses wrote down the words of the song and taught it to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord commissioned Joshua son of Nun with these words: “Be strong and courageous, for you must bring the people of Israel into the land I swore to give them. I will be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had finished writing this entire body of instruction in a book,
speaker: Narrator

text: he gave this command to the Levites who carried the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take this Book of Instruction and place it beside the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord your God, so it may remain there as a witness against the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I know how rebellious and stubborn you are. Even now, while I am still alive and am here with you, you have rebelled against the Lord. How much more rebellious will you be after my death!
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now summon all the elders and officials of your tribes, so that I can speak to them directly and call heaven and earth to witness against them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know that after my death you will become utterly corrupt and will turn from the way I have commanded you to follow. In the days to come, disaster will come down on you, for you will do what is evil in the Lord’s sight, making him very angry with your actions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses recited this entire song publicly to the assembly of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Listen, O heavens, and I will speak!
    Hear, O earth, the words that I say!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let my teaching fall on you like rain;
    let my speech settle like dew.
Let my words fall like rain on tender grass,
    like gentle showers on young plants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will proclaim the name of the Lord;
    how glorious is our God!
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the Rock; his deeds are perfect.
    Everything he does is just and fair.
He is a faithful God who does no wrong;
    how just and upright he is!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But they have acted corruptly toward him;
    when they act so perversely,
are they really his children?
    They are a deceitful and twisted generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is this the way you repay the Lord,
    you foolish and senseless people?
Isn’t he your Father who created you?
    Has he not made you and established you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember the days of long ago;
    think about the generations past.
Ask your father, and he will inform you.
    Inquire of your elders, and they will tell you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Most High assigned lands to the nations,
    when he divided up the human race,
he established the boundaries of the peoples
    according to the number in his heavenly court.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For the people of Israel belong to the Lord;
    Jacob is his special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He found them in a desert land,
    in an empty, howling wasteland.
He surrounded them and watched over them;
    he guarded them as he would guard his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like an eagle that rouses her chicks
    and hovers over her young,
so he spread his wings to take them up
    and carried them safely on his pinions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord alone guided them;
    they followed no foreign gods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He let them ride over the highlands
    and feast on the crops of the fields.
He nourished them with honey from the rock
    and olive oil from the stony ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He fed them yogurt from the herd
    and milk from the flock,
    together with the fat of lambs.
He gave them choice rams from Bashan, and goats,
    together with the choicest wheat.
You drank the finest wine,
    made from the juice of grapes.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They stirred up his jealousy by worshiping foreign gods;
    they provoked his fury with detestable deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They offered sacrifices to demons, which are not God,
    to gods they had not known before,
to new gods only recently arrived,
    to gods their ancestors had never feared.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You neglected the Rock who had fathered you;
    you forgot the God who had given you birth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord saw this and drew back,
    provoked to anger by his own sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, ‘I will abandon them;
    then see what becomes of them.
For they are a twisted generation,
    children without integrity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For my anger blazes forth like fire
    and burns to the depths of the grave.
It devours the earth and all its crops
    and ignites the foundations of the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will heap disasters upon them
    and shoot them down with my arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will weaken them with famine,
    burning fever, and deadly disease.
I will send the fangs of wild beasts
    and poisonous snakes that glide in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Outside, the sword will bring death,
    and inside, terror will strike
both young men and young women,
    both infants and the aged.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would have annihilated them,
    wiping out even the memory of them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I feared the taunt of Israel’s enemy,
    who might misunderstand and say,
“Our own power has triumphed!
    The Lord had nothing to do with this!”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But Israel is a senseless nation;
    the people are foolish, without understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh, that they were wise and could understand this!
    Oh, that they might know their fate!
speaker: Narrator

text:
How could one person chase a thousand of them,
    and two people put ten thousand to flight,
unless their Rock had sold them,
    unless the Lord had given them up?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the rock of our enemies is not like our Rock,
    as even they recognize.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their vine grows from the vine of Sodom,
    from the vineyards of Gomorrah.
Their grapes are poison,
    and their clusters are bitter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their wine is the venom of serpents,
    the deadly poison of cobras.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord says, ‘Am I not storing up these things,
    sealing them away in my treasury?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will take revenge; I will pay them back.
    In due time their feet will slip.
Their day of disaster will arrive,
    and their destiny will overtake them.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, the Lord will give justice to his people,
    and he will change his mind about his servants,
when he sees their strength is gone
    and no one is left, slave or free.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he will ask, ‘Where are their gods,
    the rocks they fled to for refuge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where now are those gods,
    who ate the fat of their sacrifices
    and drank the wine of their offerings?
Let those gods arise and help you!
    Let them provide you with shelter!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Now I raise my hand to heaven
    and declare, “As surely as I live,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I sharpen my flashing sword
    and begin to carry out justice,
I will take revenge on my enemies
    and repay those who reject me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make my arrows drunk with blood,
    and my sword will devour flesh—
the blood of the slaughtered and the captives,
    and the heads of the enemy leaders.”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Rejoice with him, you heavens,
    and let all of God’s angels worship him.
Rejoice with his people, you Gentiles,
    and let all the angels be strengthened in him.
For he will avenge the blood of his children;
    he will take revenge against his enemies.
He will repay those who hate him
    and cleanse his people’s land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses came with Joshua son of Nun and recited all the words of this song to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses had finished reciting all these words to the people of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: he added: “Take to heart all the words of warning I have given you today. Pass them on as a command to your children so they will obey every word of these instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: These instructions are not empty words—they are your life! By obeying them you will enjoy a long life in the land you will occupy when you cross the Jordan River.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go to Moab, to the mountains east of the river, and climb Mount Nebo, which is across from Jericho. Look out across the land of Canaan, the land I am giving to the people of Israel as their own special possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will die there on the mountain. You will join your ancestors, just as Aaron, your brother, died on Mount Hor and joined his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For both of you betrayed me with the Israelites at the waters of Meribah at Kadesh in the wilderness of Zin. You failed to demonstrate my holiness to the people of Israel there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you will see the land from a distance, but you may not enter the land I am giving to the people of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the blessing that Moses, the man of God, gave to the people of Israel before his death:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord came from Mount Sinai
    and dawned upon us from Mount Seir;
he shone forth from Mount Paran
    and came from Meribah-kadesh
    with flaming fire at his right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, he loves his people;
    all his holy ones are in his hands.
They follow in his steps
    and accept his teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses gave us the Lord’s instruction,
    the special possession of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord became king in Israel—
    when the leaders of the people assembled,
    when the tribes of Israel gathered as one.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribe of Reuben:
“Let the tribe of Reuben live and not die out,
    though they are few in number.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribe of Judah:
“O Lord, hear the cry of Judah
    and bring them together as a people.
Give them strength to defend their cause;
    help them against their enemies!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribe of Levi:
“O Lord, you have given your Thummim and Urim—the sacred lots—
    to your faithful servants the Levites.
You put them to the test at Massah
    and struggled with them at the waters of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Levites obeyed your word
    and guarded your covenant.
They were more loyal to you
    than to their own parents.
They ignored their relatives
    and did not acknowledge their own children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They teach your regulations to Jacob;
    they give your instructions to Israel.
They present incense before you
    and offer whole burnt offerings on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bless the ministry of the Levites, O Lord,
    and accept all the work of their hands.
Hit their enemies where it hurts the most;
    strike down their foes so they never rise again.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribe of Benjamin:
“The people of Benjamin are loved by the Lord
    and live in safety beside him.
He surrounds them continuously
    and preserves them from every harm.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribes of Joseph:
“May their land be blessed by the Lord
    with the precious gift of dew from the heavens
    and water from beneath the earth;
speaker: Narrator

text:
with the rich fruit that grows in the sun,
    and the rich harvest produced each month;
speaker: Narrator

text:
with the finest crops of the ancient mountains,
    and the abundance from the everlasting hills;
speaker: Narrator

text:
with the best gifts of the earth and its bounty,
    and the favor of the one who appeared in the burning bush.
May these blessings rest on Joseph’s head,
    crowning the brow of the prince among his brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joseph has the majesty of a young bull;
    he has the horns of a wild ox.
He will gore distant nations,
    even to the ends of the earth.
This is my blessing for the multitudes of Ephraim
    and the thousands of Manasseh.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribes of Zebulun and Issachar:
“May the people of Zebulun prosper in their travels.
    May the people of Issachar prosper at home in their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They summon the people to the mountain
    to offer proper sacrifices there.
They benefit from the riches of the sea
    and the hidden treasures in the sand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribe of Gad:
“Blessed is the one who enlarges Gad’s territory!
    Gad is poised there like a lion
    to tear off an arm or a head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people of Gad took the best land for themselves;
    a leader’s share was assigned to them.
When the leaders of the people were assembled,
    they carried out the Lord’s justice
    and obeyed his regulations for Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribe of Dan:
“Dan is a lion’s cub,
    leaping out from Bashan.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said this about the tribe of Naphtali:
“O Naphtali, you are rich in favor
    and full of the Lord’s blessings;
    may you possess the west and the south.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
May the bolts of your gates be of iron and bronze;
    may you be secure all your days.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There is no one like the God of Israel.
    He rides across the heavens to help you,
    across the skies in majestic splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eternal God is your refuge,
    and his everlasting arms are under you.
He drives out the enemy before you;
    he cries out, ‘Destroy them!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Israel will live in safety,
    prosperous Jacob in security,
in a land of grain and new wine,
    while the heavens drop down dew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How blessed you are, O Israel!
    Who else is like you, a people saved by the Lord?
He is your protecting shield
    and your triumphant sword!
Your enemies will cringe before you,
    and you will stomp on their backs!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went up to Mount Nebo from the plains of Moab and climbed Pisgah Peak, which is across from Jericho. And the Lord showed him the whole land, from Gilead as far as Dan;
speaker: Narrator

text: all the land of Naphtali; the land of Ephraim and Manasseh; all the land of Judah, extending to the Mediterranean Sea;
speaker: Narrator

text: the Negev; the Jordan Valley with Jericho—the city of palms—as far as Zoar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “This is the land I promised on oath to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob when I said, ‘I will give it to your descendants.’ I have now allowed you to see it with your own eyes, but you will not enter the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses, the servant of the Lord, died there in the land of Moab, just as the Lord had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord buried him in a valley near Beth-peor in Moab, but to this day no one knows the exact place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was 120 years old when he died, yet his eyesight was clear, and he was as strong as ever.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel mourned for Moses on the plains of Moab for thirty days, until the customary period of mourning was over.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joshua son of Nun was full of the spirit of wisdom, for Moses had laid his hands on him. So the people of Israel obeyed him, doing just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: There has never been another prophet in Israel like Moses, whom the Lord knew face to face.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent him to perform all the miraculous signs and wonders in the land of Egypt against Pharaoh, and all his servants, and his entire land.
speaker: Narrator

text: With mighty power, Moses performed terrifying acts in the sight of all Israel.
speaker: Narrator
